awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Networks: Probabilistic Models and Inference Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Networks play a fundamental role in many areas of science, such as the network of friendships in sociology and protein-protein interaction networks in biology. At the heart of problems in these areas is a need to understand underlying structures in the relevant network, such as geometric structure and community structure. Many networks evolve and grow over time and this leaves a mark on their underlying structure. The broad goal of this project is to understand how the growth of a network interacts with other underlying structures such as community structure. The project focuses on a mathematical understanding of fundamental network models that are common to many applications. Developing such a mathematical theory can lead to fundamental insights that can be applied across multiple disciplines, as well as to connections between disciplines that can lead to further cross-disciplinary explorations. 

This project studies a wide range of problems involving probabilistic models of dynamic networks. The project aims to build novel probabilistic theory to analyze and provide insight into such models, as well as to build and analyze novel models that shed light on new phenomena. A main focus is on models of growing networks, which are abundant in the social sciences, economics, and biology. In particular, the project will investigate the influence of the seed graph in growing random graph models. In doing so, the award will develop novel probabilistic tools to obtain quantitative results on the limits of branching processes, which are of independent interest more widely in probability theory and related fields. A second theme of the project will be the study of community detection in growing networks by introducing probabilistic models of growing networks with community structure. This perspective lends itself to relevant new questions, such as detecting communities from networks observed at multiple time points. Finally, the award will also study stochastic processes on networks, resulting in enhanced understanding of how information spreads on networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on improving our understanding of the mathematical foundations of dynamic networks. Such networks play a fundamental role in many areas of science, such as social networks, protein-protein interaction networks in biology, and more. In research supported by this grant, we developed novel probabilistic models of networks which focused on relevant modern scenarios, such as the fact that many problems involve multiple correlated networks (for instance, different social networks). We subsequently developed novel mathematical theory to uncover the fundamental limits of natural statistical detection and estimation questions, such as detecting correlation and recovering communities. 

A main focus of the project was studying randomly growing graphs. We developed several novel models of correlated randomly growing graphs, and our accompanying mathematical theory connected fundamental correlation detection questions with the influence of the seed property of growing graphs. We also developed an array of statistics to distinguish different graph growth mechanisms, which help answer central conceptual questions in network science. 

Another main line of research of the project concerned questions about community recovery in correlated networks. Our results precisely characterize when communities can be exactly recovered from multiple correlated networks. In particular, our results show how correlated networks can be harnessed for improved algorithms and statistical inference procedures for community recovery tasks. This opens the door to a multitude of applications, for instance in social networks and computational biology. To achieve these results, we developed a novel algorithm that carefully synthesizes community recovery and graph matching algorithms. 

A third major theme of the project concerned stochastic processes on networks. We obtained novel results on rumor source detection, which raise important questions about the robustness of anonymity guarantees when spreading information in social networks. We also studied opinion dynamic models, focusing on understanding how various interventions change measures of disagreement and polarization. Our results give insight into the extremely timely issue of societal polarization. 

This project also supported further work in related areas. Work on random graphs included advances in finding cliques using adaptive edge queries and in detecting latent high-dimensional geometry. In addition, significant advances were made in fundamental mathematical problems arising in computational biology, including various sequence reconstruction problems and a probabilistic combinatorial optimization problem arising in DNA synthesis. 

The project had a significant educational component. The PI actively mentored several PhD students, as well as undergraduate students who are now pursuing graduate studies in STEM fields; the research progress described above was obtained in joint work with them. The grant also facilitated many professional development opportunities, such as participation at workshops and summer schools. Combined, the efforts of this project contribute to maintaining a strong, robust, and diverse workforce in the mathematical sciences.
